title: To Kill a Mockingbird
author: Harper Lee
summary: A coming-of-age story set in the American South, focusing on race, justice, and moral growth as seen through the eyes of a young girl.

author: George Orwell
summary: A dystopian novel that explores the dangers of totalitarianism, surveillance, and loss of individuality in a society ruled by Big Brother.

title: The Great Gatsby
author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
summary: A critique of the American Dream told through the tragic story of Jay Gatsby, a wealthy man longing for a lost love.

title: Pride and Prejudice
author: Jane Austen
summary: A romantic novel about manners, marriage, and morality in 19th-century England, centered on the witty and independent Elizabeth Bennet.

title: Moby-Dick
author: Herman Melville
summary: An epic tale of obsession and revenge, chronicling Captain Ahab’s relentless pursuit of the white whale, Moby Dick.

title: Brave New World
author: Aldous Huxley
summary: A futuristic society driven by technological control and social conditioning, questioning the cost of a seemingly perfect world.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
author: J.D. Salinger
summary: A story about teenage alienation and rebellion, narrated by the cynical and disillusioned Holden Caulfield.

title: The Hobbit
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
summary: A fantasy adventure where Bilbo Baggins, a reluctant hobbit, embarks on a quest to help dwarves reclaim their homeland.

title: Frankenstein
author: Mary Shelley
summary: A gothic novel about a scientist who creates life and the tragic consequences of playing god.

title: Crime and Punishment
author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
summary: A psychological exploration of guilt, redemption, and morality as a man wrestles with the aftermath of committing murder.
